description:
Mellicta athalia, commonly known as the heath fritillary, is a butterfly species belonging to the family Nymphalidae. It is a medium-sized butterfly with distinctive orange-brown wings, marked with dark brown or black spots and patterns.

The heath fritillary is found in various parts of Europe, including the UK, France, Germany, and Scandinavia. Its preferred habitats are damp, open woodlands, and grasslands where its larval host plants, such as the common cow-wheat (Melampyrum pratense), are present.

The butterfly's life cycle involves egg-laying, larval development, and eventual metamorphosis into the adult form. The larvae feed on the leaves and flowers of the host plants, while the adults primarily feed on nectar from various wildflowers.

Due to habitat loss and other environmental factors, the heath fritillary is considered a threatened species in some regions. Conservation efforts, such as habitat management and protection, are essential for the preservation of this distinctive and ecologically important butterfly.
